IAM.Question: What is a proper definition of an IAM Role?
IAM.A: IAM Users in multiple User Groups
IAM.B: An IAM entity that defines a set of permissions for making requests to AWS services, and will be used by an AWS service
IAM.C: An IAM entity that defines a password policy for IAM Users
IAM.D: Permissions assigned to IAM Users to perform actions
IAM.Explanation: Some AWS services need to perform actions on your behalf. To do so, you assign permissions to AWS services with IAM Roles.

IAM.Question: Which of the following is an IAM Security Tool?
IAM.Explanation: IAM Credentials report lists all your AWS Account's IAM Users and the status of their various credentials.

IAM.Question: Which answer is INCORRECT regarding IAM Users?
IAM.A: IAM Users can belong to multiple User Groups
IAM.B: IAM Users don't have to belong to a User Group
IAM.C: IAM Policies can be attached directly to IAM Users
IAM.D: IAM Users access AWS services using root account credentials
IAM.Explanation: IAM Users access AWS services using their own credentials (username & password or Access Keys).

IAM.Question: Which of the following is an IAM best practice?
IAM.A: Create several IAM Users for one physical person
IAM.B: Share your AWS account credentials with your colleague, so he can perform a task for you
IAM.C: Don't use the root user account
IAM.D: Do not enable MFA for easier access
IAM.Explanation: Use the root account only to create your first IAM User and a few account/service management tasks. For everyday tasks, use IAM User.

IAM.Question: What are IAM Policies?
IAM.A: A set of policies defines how AWS accounts interact with each other
IAM.B: JSON documents that define a set of permissions for making requests to AWS services, and can be used by IAM Users, User Groups, and IAM Roles
IAM.C: A set of policies that define a password for IAM Users
IAM.D: A set of policies defined by AWS that show how customers interact with AWS
IAM.Explanation: JSON documents that define a set of permissions for making requests to AWS services and can be used by IAM Users, Groups, and Roles.

IAM.Question: Which principle should you apply regarding IAM Permissions?
IAM.C: Grant more permissions if your employee asks you to
IAM.Explanation: Don't give more permissions than the user needs.

IAM.Question: What should you do to increase your root account security?
IAM.A: Remove permissions from the root account
IAM.B: Only access AWS services through AWS Command Line Interface (CLI)
IAM.D: Don't create IAM Users, only access your AWS account using the root account
IAM.Explanation: When you enable MFA, this adds another security layer. Even if your password is stolen or lost, your account is not compromised.

IAM.Question: IAM User Groups can contain IAM Users and other User Groups.
IAM.Explanation: IAM User Groups can contain only IAM Users.

IAM.Question: An IAM policy consists of one or more statements. A statement in an IAM Policy consists of the following, EXCEPT:
IAM.Explanation: A statement in an IAM Policy consists of Sid, Effect, Principal, Action, Resource, and Condition. “Version” is part of the policy itself, not the statement.

IAM.Question: According to the AWS Shared Responsibility Model, which of the following is AWS responsibility?
IAM.A: Rotate Access Key for IAM Users
IAM.B: Enable MFA for the root account and all IAM Users
IAM.C: IAM Users, User Groups, and IAM Policies
IAM.Explanation: AWS is responsible for protecting the infrastructure that runs all of the services offered in the AWS Cloud. This includes the hardware, software, networking, and facilities that support AWS Cloud services. Customers are responsible for managing their own data, applications, and configurations within AWS

Monitoring Quiz.Question: You have a couple of EC2 instances in which you would like their Standard CloudWatch Metrics to be collected every 1 minute. What should you do?
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: This is a paid offering and is disabled by default. When enabled, the EC2 instance's metrics are available in 1-minute periods.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: High-Resolution Custom Metrics can have a minimum resolution of ..........................
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: "1 second" is the minimum resolution for High-Resolution Metrics in CloudWatch.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: You have an RDS DB instance that's configured to push database logs to CloudWatch. You want to create a CloudWatch alarm if there's an "Error" found in the logs. How?
Monitoring Quiz.A: Create a CloudWatch Logs Metric Filter for the keyword "Error", then create a CloudWatch Alarm on that Metric Filter
Monitoring Quiz.B: Create a scheduled CloudWatch Event that triggers AWS Lambda every 1 hour, scans logs, and notify via SNS
Monitoring Quiz.C: Create AWS Config Rule monitoring "Error" in logs and notify via SNS
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: Use a Metric Filter looking for "Error", then create an alarm on it.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: You have an app hosted on EC2 instances managed by Auto Scaling Group with min capacity 2 and CloudWatch Alarm in ALARM state. What's the effect?
Monitoring Quiz.A: One EC2 instance will terminate, ASG capacity goes to 1
Monitoring Quiz.C: Alarm remains ALARM but won't reduce EC2 below min capacity
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: ASG capacity won't go below min; alarm stays ALARM.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: How to monitor memory usage in EC2 with CloudWatch?
Monitoring Quiz.B: EC2 pushes memory usage by default
Monitoring Quiz.C: Use Unified CloudWatch Agent to push custom metric
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: Unified CloudWatch Agent needed as default does not push memory.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: CloudWatch Alarm on a High-Resolution Metric triggers as often as?
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: Can specify alarms as frequent as 10 or 30 seconds.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: You want to evaluate impact of a configuration change. Which AWS service?
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: CloudWatch allows monitoring and analyzing application performance.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: Someone terminated an EC2 instance with sensitive data. Which service helps identify who and when?
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: CloudTrail logs and shows activity including termination events.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: CloudTrail enabled across all Regions to detect unusual activity. Which to use?
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: CloudTrail Insights detects unusual activity.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: Teammate terminated EC2 4 months ago, you need to review API calls. What to do?
Monitoring Quiz.A: Use CloudTrail Event History in Console
Monitoring Quiz.B: Analyze CloudTrail logs in S3 with Athena
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: Use Athena to analyze older CloudTrail logs in S3.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: Resource config changed and non-compliant. Which service to find who made change?
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: CloudTrail tracks who made changes.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: How to test CloudWatch Alarm responding to traffic increase in cost-effective way?
Monitoring Quiz.A: Setup global EC2 fleet to raise requests
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: Use CLI set-alarm-state to simulate alarm.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: How to push custom metric data to CloudWatch API?
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: PutMetricData is used to push custom metrics.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: CloudWatch Logs auto-expire after 7 days by default?
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: By default, logs never expire.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: Log Retention Policy in CloudWatch Logs defined at which level?
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: Policy is set at Log Groups level.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: X-Ray traces missing after Elastic Beanstalk deploy, cause?
Monitoring Quiz.B: Need IAM permission from X-Ray Console
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: Daemon config file required for Beanstalk.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: X-Ray traces missing after EC2 deploy via CodeDeploy, cause?
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: Daemon must run for X-Ray to function.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: Traces missing despite X-Ray daemon running on EC2 via CodeDeploy, cause?
Monitoring Quiz.A: IAM role missing permission to send data
Monitoring Quiz.C: EC2 in Auto Scaling Group required
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: IAM role must have sending permission.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: CodePipeline fails finding Elastic Beanstalk environment, next step?
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: Use CloudTrail logs to find deletions.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: Configure X-Ray daemon to send traces from multiple accounts to central account?
Monitoring Quiz.A: Create IAM user, generate load keys to other accounts
Monitoring Quiz.B: Create IAM role in central account, then roles in other accounts to assume it
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: Best practice to use IAM roles.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: Add info to X-Ray traces enabling efficient search and filter?
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: Annotations allow custom key-value info for filtering.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: AWS service for cross-account tracing and visualization?
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: AWS X-Ray supports cross-account tracing.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: APIs for writing to X-Ray, EXCEPT?
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: BatchGetTraces is read-only API.

Monitoring Quiz.Question: X-Ray SDK records first request ..., and ... of additional requests?
Monitoring Quiz.Explanation: Records first request each second, and 5% of subsequent.

Lambda.Question: You have created a Lambda function that typically will take around 1 hour to process some data. The code works fine when you run it locally on your machine, but when you invoke the Lambda function it fails with a "timeout" error after 3 seconds. What should you do?
Lambda.A: Configure your Lambda's timeout to 25 minutes
Lambda.B: Configure your Lambda's memory to 10 GB
Lambda.C: Run your code somewhere else (e.g., EC2 instance)
Lambda.Explanation: Lambda's maximum execution time is 15 minutes. Since your process takes 1 hour, you should use an EC2 instance or another service suitable for long-running tasks.

Lambda.Question: Which of the following is the best way to inject a dynamic DB_URL variable into your Lambda function's code?
Lambda.A: Use Lambda’s Environment Variables
Lambda.B: Place it in the code and create a zip file
Lambda.C: Place it in the code itself
Lambda.Explanation: Lambda’s Environment Variables allow you to adjust your function’s behavior without updating code.

Lambda.Question: A Lambda function that's invoked asynchronously, fails to process from time to time after 3 retries. To troubleshoot the issue, you would like to collect and analyze these events later on. What is the best practice you can do?
Lambda.A: Add logging statements for all events in your Lambda function, then filter CloudWatch Logs
Lambda.B: Invoke your function synchronously
Lambda.C: Add a Dead Letter Queue (DLQ) to send messages to SQS
Lambda.D: Add a Dead Letter Queue (DLQ) to send messages to SNS
Lambda.Explanation: This is good as SQS will hold the failed messages for some days so we have time to consume and analyze them.

Lambda.Question: You have enabled a Dead Letter Queue (DLQ) for your Lambda function and configured it to send failed messages to SNS. While testing, you don't see any events there even though you can tell from CloudWatch metrics that you have failures. What is most likely the reason for this?
Lambda.A: AWS SNS is having outages
Lambda.B: Your Lambda function's execution role is missing permissions
Lambda.C: You should use SQS instead, there's no Lambda DLQ for SNS
Lambda.Explanation: The Lambda function’s execution role must have permissions to send messages to the DLQ destination (SNS in this case). If permissions are missing, failures won’t be sent to SNS even if CloudWatch shows function errors.

Lambda.Question: You have enabled X-Ray integration on your Lambda function but it doesn't work. What is a possible cause for this?
Lambda.A: Check IAM permissions in your Lambda function's execution role
Lambda.B: You need to run the X-Ray daemon as a dependency in your deployment package
Lambda.C: You need to open a ticket with AWS Support
Lambda.Explanation: The Lambda function's execution role must have the necessary permissions for X-Ray tracing. If the correct IAM permissions are missing, X-Ray integration will not work as expected.

Lambda.Question: While updating a Lambda function, you get the following exception: “An error occurred: InvalidParameterValueException when calling the UpdateFunctionCode operation: Unzipped size must be smaller than 262144000 bytes”. What might be the possible cause of this error?
Lambda.A: You have uploaded a deployment package .zip larger than 50 MB to AWS Lambda
Lambda.B: The uncompressed deployment package .zip exceeds AWS Lambda Limits
Lambda.C: The deployment package .zip file is corrupted
Lambda.Explanation: The uncompressed deployment package (.zip) exceeds the AWS Lambda limits. The unzipped size must be smaller than 262,144,000 bytes (250MB), which is an AWS Lambda restriction.

Lambda.Question: A Lambda function makes requests to 3rd party API. To successfully make the requests, the 3rd party API requires you to send a token which is a long string of 8 KB. Where should you place this token?
Lambda.A: Place it in the Lambda function's environment variables
Lambda.B: Place it in the deployment package .zip file
Lambda.Explanation: AWS Lambda environment variables have a size limit (4KB per variable, 8KB total). Since the token is 8KB, it exceeds the limit. Placing the token within the deployment package .zip file allows your function to access it without exceeding these environment variable restrictions.

Lambda.Question: Every time you release a Lambda function version, it gets a new number and you have to manually update all the AWS resources linked to your function (e.g., event triggers). What should you do?
Lambda.A: Use Lambda Aliases, and update the Alias to point to the new version
Lambda.B: Use AWS CloudFormation to update all the links automatically
Lambda.C: Just always use $LATEST and never worry again
Lambda.Explanation: Lambda Aliases let you abstract version numbers, so you only update the alias to point to the new version; resources can stay linked to the alias.

Lambda.Question: You have updated a Lambda function and created a new version. Now, you want to test out the new version and ensure it can sustain production traffic. You are risk-averse and don't want to take down your whole application. What should you do?
Lambda.A: Create a new Lambda function and test there
Lambda.B: Use Lambda Aliases, and point to the new and old versions, then assign weights
Lambda.Explanation: Lambda Aliases allow you to route a certain percentage of traffic to the new version and the rest to the old version (weighted aliases), enabling safe, incremental rollout and risk mitigation.

Lambda.Question: You have a Lambda function used to retrieve data from an RDS DB instance. Each time the Lambda function is invoked, it establishes a new connection to your database. These connections make a load on your database and degrade its performance. So, you tell your developers to use long-lived database connections. They tell you that...
Lambda.A: It's impossible, AWS Lambda containers are created and destroyed every time they are called
Lambda.B: They will move the database connection object outside of the function handler
Lambda.C: They will use an ElastiCache cluster to proxy requests to the RDS DB instance
Lambda.Explanation: By moving the database connection object outside of the function handler, the Lambda container can reuse the connection if the container is reused (warm start), reducing the number of new connections created and improving performance.

Lambda.Question: Your Lambda function written in Node.js wants to connect to an RDS PostgreSQL database in your VPC. The Lambda function must use the Node.js driver for PostgreSQL to connect to the database. How do you bundle your Lambda function to add the dependencies?
Lambda.A: Put the function and the dependencies in one folder and zip them together
Lambda.B: Zip the function as-is with a package.json file so that AWS Lambda can resolve the dependencies for you
Lambda.C: Zip the function and the dependencies separately and upload them in AWS Lambda as two parts
Lambda.D: Upload the code through the AWS Console and upload the dependencies as a .zip
Lambda.Explanation: You should put the function and all its dependencies (including the Node.js PostgreSQL driver) together in one folder, and then zip this folder before uploading to AWS Lambda. AWS Lambda requires all dependencies to be included in the deployment package unless specifically handled by Lambda Layers or other advanced methods.

Lambda.Question: How do you declare a Lambda function in a CloudFormation template?
Lambda.A: Upload all the code to AWS CodeCommit and refer to the CodeCommit repository in AWS::Lambda::Function block
Lambda.B: Upload all the code to AWS CodeDeploy and refer to the CodeDeploy application in AWS::Lambda::Function block
Lambda.C: Upload all the code as a folder to an S3 bucket and refer to the folder in AWS::Lambda::Function block
Lambda.D: Upload all the code as a .zip file to an S3 bucket and refer to the object in AWS::Lambda::Function block
Lambda.Explanation: The preferred and correct method is to upload all Lambda code as a .zip file to an S3 bucket. Then, you reference the S3 object from within the AWS::Lambda::Function block in your CloudFormation template. This allows CloudFormation to deploy the Lambda using the packaged code.

Lambda.Question: Which of the following allows you to deploy your Lambda function globally so that requests made to a CloudFront distribution are filtered at the AWS Edge Locations?
Lambda.A: Lambda@Edge
Lambda.B: Deploy Lambda in a global VPC
Lambda.C: Deploy Lambda in S3 Bucket with S3 Cross-Region Replication enabled
Lambda.Explanation: Lambda@Edge enables you to run Lambda functions at AWS Edge Locations globally, allowing you to intercept and process CloudFront requests close to end users for lower latency and flexible content handling.

Lambda.Question: What is the recommended way to store temporary files used by your Lambda function that will be discarded when the function stops execution?
Lambda.A: Use the local directory "/opt"
Lambda.B: Create a tmp directory in the source zip file and use it
Lambda.C: Use the local directory /tmp
Lambda.Explanation: The recommended way to store temporary files in AWS Lambda is to use the local directory /tmp. This directory is specifically designated for temporary storage, is cleared between invocations, and is limited in size (512MB by default). Files stored here are erased when the function execution ends.

Lambda.Question: The maximum size for a Lambda function /tmp space is .........................
Lambda.A: 64 MB
Lambda.B: 128 MB
Lambda.Explanation: The /tmp directory in AWS Lambda provides temporary disk space accessible during function execution. The maximum size for this space is 10,240MB (or 10GB), allowing for storage of files needed during runtime, but this space is cleared between invocations.

Lambda.Question: Which of the following AWS services allows you to schedule your Lambda function to be invoked every hour?
Lambda.A: Amazon S3
Lambda.B: Simple Queue Service (SQS)
Lambda.C: Amazon EventBridge
Lambda.Explanation: Amazon EventBridge (formerly CloudWatch Events) allows you to create rules to invoke your Lambda function on a schedule (e.g., every hour).

Lambda.Question: To use your Lambda function with an Application Load Balancer, the Lambda function must be registered with ..............................
Lambda.A: An Event Source Mapping
Lambda.B: A Target Group
Lambda.C: An Asynchronous Invocation
Lambda.Explanation: To use a Lambda function with an Application Load Balancer (ALB), the Lambda must be registered as a target in a Target Group. The ALB then routes requests to the Lambda function using this target group.

Lambda.Question: You have enabled and configured Event Notifications in your S3 bucket to invoke a Lambda function every time an object is uploaded to your S3 bucket. You have noticed that there's duplicate logging into CloudWatch Logs with the same request ID. What do you think is the reason for this?
Lambda.A: The Lambda function has failed and retries have happened
Lambda.B: The S3 bucket invoked your Lambda function too many times
Lambda.C: The Lambda function timeout is too low
Lambda.Explanation: When a Lambda function fails to execute successfully, AWS automatically retries the invocation. This can cause multiple log entries with the same request ID in CloudWatch Logs, as the same event is retried and logged again.

Lambda.Question: Which of the following AWS service does NOT require a Lambda Event Source Mapping?
Lambda.A: DynamoDB Streams
Lambda.B: Kinesis Data Streams
Lambda.C: Simple Queue Service (SQS)
Lambda.Explanation: SNS is asynchronous and directly invokes Lambda functions without the need for Event Source Mapping.

Lambda.Question: Which of the following is the recommended way to send the result of an asynchronous Lambda function to an SQS queue?
Lambda.A: Write it in the Lambda function code
Lambda.B: Use Lambda Destinations
Lambda.C: Use Lambda Layers
Lambda.Explanation: The recommended way is to use Lambda Destinations, which allows you to route the result of an asynchronous Lambda invocation to an SQS queue, SNS topic, another Lambda function, or EventBridge, based on success or failure.

Lambda.Question: AWS Lambda natively supports the following programming languages, EXCEPT ....................
Lambda.A: Go
Lambda.B: Python
Lambda.Explanation: AWS Lambda natively supports Go, Python, Node.js, and Java, but it does not natively support C++. C++ is not available as a native Lambda runtime, and running C++ code would require using a custom runtime or wrapping C++ binaries.

Lambda.Question: You have a Lambda function written in Python which has a lot of dependencies. Each time you update and deploy your function, it takes 15 minutes to natively compile these dependencies and therefore deployments have been really slow. What do you suggest?
Lambda.A: Store the dependencies in an S3 bucket
Lambda.B: Build the dependencies on an EC2 instance
Lambda.C: Migrate to Node.js
Lambda.D: Create a Lambda Layer and include all the dependencies in it
Lambda.Explanation: By creating a Lambda Layer and including all the dependencies in it, you can avoid recompiling and redeploying dependencies every time you update your Lambda function, greatly speeding up deployments.

Lambda.Question: You want to give another AWS account access to invoke a Lambda function in your AWS account. Which of the following can NOT be used to do so?
Lambda.A: Lambda Execution Role
Lambda.B: Lambda Resource-based Policy
Lambda.C: Cross-account IAM Role
Lambda.Explanation: A Lambda Execution Role defines permissions for the Lambda function to access AWS services/resources, not for others to invoke the function. To allow another AWS account to invoke your Lambda, you would use a resource-based policy or a cross-account IAM role.

Lambda.Question: You have a CloudFormation template that declares a Lambda function. The Lambda function's code is stored in an S3 bucket with Versioning enabled. You use "S3Bucket", "S3Key", and "S3ObjectVersion" in the CloudFormation template to reference the code. You have updated the Lambda function's code then uploaded it to S3, but the function hasn't been updated. What should you do?
Lambda.A: Update "S3Bucket" to reference the updated code
Lambda.B: Update "S3Key" to reference the updated code
Lambda.C: Update "S3ObjectVersion" to reference the updated code
Lambda.Explanation: When using versioned objects in S3, CloudFormation references the Lambda code by "S3ObjectVersion". If you update the code in S3 but do not update the "S3ObjectVersion" in your template, CloudFormation will not detect a change. To update the function, specify the new "S3ObjectVersion" that matches your latest upload.

Lambda.Question: Which of the following Lambda features can NOT be used to create a custom runtime if it isn't natively supported by AWS Lambda?
Lambda.A: Lambda Layers
Lambda.B: Lambda Destinations
Lambda.C: Lambda Container Images
Lambda.Explanation: "Lambda Destinations" are used to handle function execution results (e.g., send outputs to SQS, SNS, etc.) but cannot be used to build or customize a Lambda runtime. Only Lambda Layers and Lambda Container Images help build or extend support for custom runtimes.

Lambda.Question: You are using CodeDeploy for automated deployments to your Lambda function. You updated your Lambda function's code and want to deploy the new version, test it with a small amount of traffic, then totally shift to the new version. Which CodeDeploy deployment type do you recommend?
Lambda.A: Linear
Lambda.B: AllAtOnce
Lambda.C: Canary
Lambda.Explanation: The "Canary" deployment type allows you to deploy the new version to a small portion of traffic first, verify its functionality, and then shift all traffic to the new version. This approach helps minimize risk and allows for easy rollback if issues are detected.

Dynamo DB.Question: Before you create a DynamoDB table, you need to provision the EC2 instance the DynamoDB table will be running on.
Dynamo DB.Explanation: DynamoDB is serverless with no servers to provision, patch, or manage and no software to install, maintain or operate. It automatically scales tables up and down to adjust for capacity and maintain performance. It provides both provisioned (specify RCU & WCU) and on-demand (pay for what you use) capacity modes.

Dynamo DB.Question: You have provisioned a DynamoDB table with 10 RCUs and 10 WCUs. A month later you want to increase the RCU to handle more read traffic. What should you do?
Dynamo DB.A: Increase RCU and keep WCU the same
Dynamo DB.B: You need to increase both RCU and WCU
Dynamo DB.Explanation: RCU and WCU are decoupled, so you can increase/decrease each value separately.

Dynamo DB.Question: You have an e-commerce website ... last year due to the huge traffic you had the ProvisionedThroughputExceededException exception. What would you do to prevent this error from happening again?
Dynamo DB.A: Increase the RCU to a very high value
Dynamo DB.C: Migrate the database away from DynamoDB for the time of the sale
Dynamo DB.Explanation: DynamoDB Accelerator (DAX) caches the most frequently used data, offloading reads from hot keys and preventing ProvisionedThroughputExceededException.

Dynamo DB.Question: You developed a mobile app using DynamoDB as a datastore. You want to automate sending welcome emails to new users after they sign up. What is the most efficient way to achieve this?
Dynamo DB.A: Schedule a Lambda function to run every minute using CloudWatch Events, scan the entire table looking for new users
Dynamo DB.C: Enable DynamoDB Streams and configure it to invoke a Lambda function to send emails
Dynamo DB.Explanation: DynamoDB Streams + Lambda trigger allows real-time automated action in response to item-level modifications.

Dynamo DB.Question: You are running an application in production ... need to make the application run in development mode as well ... most cost-effective solution?
Dynamo DB.A: Use Provisioned Capacity Mode with Auto Scaling enabled for both development and production
Dynamo DB.B: Use Provisioned Capacity Mode with Auto Scaling enabled for production and use On-Demand Capacity Mode for development
Dynamo DB.C: Use Provisioned Capacity Mode with Auto Scaling enabled for development and use On-Demand Capacity Mode for production
Dynamo DB.D: Use On-Demand Capacity Mode for both development and production
Dynamo DB.Explanation: Use Provisioned Capacity + Auto Scaling for stable prod, and On-Demand Capacity for unpredictable development requests for cost efficiency.

Dynamo DB.Question: The maximum size of an item in a DynamoDB table is ..................
Dynamo DB.Explanation: The maximum size of an item in a DynamoDB table is 400 KB.

Dynamo DB.Question: DynamoDB tables scale ..........................
Dynamo DB.Explanation: DynamoDB tables scale horizontally by partitioning data across multiple nodes for high scalability.

Dynamo DB.Question: When your DynamoDB table's Primary Key is a combination of Partition Key + Sort Key, then .................... must be unique.
Dynamo DB.Explanation: In such tables, the combination of Partition Key and Sort Key must be unique.

Dynamo DB.Question: For a blog posts table in DynamoDB, which column should you use as Partition Key for optimal distribution and grouping of posts per blog?
Dynamo DB.Explanation: Using blog_id as the partition key allows optimal distribution and efficient queries for all posts in a blog.

Dynamo DB.Question: An application writes 12 items per second into a DynamoDB table, with each item 8 KB in size. What WCU should you choose?
An application doing Strongly Consistent reads of 10 items per second, with each item 10 KB in size. What RCU do you choose?
Dynamo DB.Explanation: 10 KB gets rounded to 12 KB. 10 * (12 KB / 4 KB) = 30 RCU.

Dynamo DB.Question: An application doing Eventually Consistent reads of 12 items per second, with each item 16 KB in size. What RCU do you choose?
Dynamo DB.Explanation: Two Eventually Consistent reads per 4 KB with 1 RCU. 12 * (16 KB / 4 KB) = 48 / 2 = 24 RCU.

Dynamo DB.Question: An app begins to receive ProvisionedThroughputExceededException exceptions from a DynamoDB table but hasn't exceeded the total provisioned RCU. What is a possible cause for this?
Dynamo DB.A: Everything is good, just the CloudWatch metrics are slow to update
Dynamo DB.B: You have a Hot Partition / Hot Key
Dynamo DB.C: There's a bug in the application's code
Dynamo DB.Explanation: RCU/WCU are spread across all table’s partitions; a hot partition or key can cause throttling even if global limits aren’t reached.

Dynamo DB.Question: You are using GetItem API call to retrieve items from a DynamoDB table. Which of the following allows you to select only certain attributes from the item?
Dynamo DB.Explanation: Use ProjectionExpression to retrieve only specific attributes from an item in DynamoDB.

Dynamo DB.Question: What is the best way to delete all the data in a DynamoDB table?
Dynamo DB.B: Use a Scan and run BatchWriteItem
Dynamo DB.C: Use a Scan and run DeleteItem
Dynamo DB.Explanation: Deleting and recreating the table is the fastest way to remove all data, compared to scanning and deleting each item individually.

Dynamo DB.Question: You want to perform a Scan operation on a DynamoDB table to retrieve all items. What should you do to increase the performance of your scan operation?
Dynamo DB.Explanation: Parallel scans allow you to divide and scan the table in segments simultaneously for faster results.

Dynamo DB.Question: You would like to make a Query to a DynamoDB table using an attribute that's NOT part of your table's Primary Key. What should you do to make this query efficient?
Dynamo DB.Explanation: A Global Secondary Index enables efficient queries on attributes that are not part of the primary key.

Dynamo DB.Question: You are designing a new DynamoDB table and want to make a Query using an attribute that's NOT part of the table's Primary Key, using the >= predicate while keeping the same Partition Key. What should you do?
Dynamo DB.Explanation: Use a Local Secondary Index for efficient queries on non-key attributes with the same partition key and sort predicates.

Dynamo DB.Question: Which Concurrency Model can be implemented using DynamoDB?
Dynamo DB.Explanation: DynamoDB supports Optimistic Locking using features like Conditional Writes and version numbers or timestamps.

Dynamo DB.Question: Which feature of DynamoDB allows you to achieve Optimistic Locking?
Dynamo DB.Explanation: Conditional Writes enable Optimistic Locking by verifying that an item hasn't changed before updating it.

Dynamo DB.Question: You are using a DynamoDB table with Provisioned RCUs and WCUs and no throttling issues, but after adding a GSI, table throttles even though CloudWatch says base RCU/WCU are fine. What should you do?
Dynamo DB.A: The LSI is throttling, so provision more RCU and WCU to LSI
Dynamo DB.B: Adding both an LSI and GSI is not recommended
Dynamo DB.C: The GSI is throttling so you need to provision more RCU and WCU to the GSI
Dynamo DB.D: CloudWatch metrics takes time to propagate
Dynamo DB.Explanation: Global Secondary Indexes (GSI) use their own RCU/WCU; if the GSI is under-provisioned, the main table can also be throttled.

Dynamo DB.Question: Which feature in DynamoDB allows you to automatically delete expired items from the table?
Dynamo DB.Explanation: TTL (Time to Live) allows DynamoDB to automatically delete expired items.

Dynamo DB.Question: Which AWS CLI option allows you to retrieve a subset of attributes from a DynamoDB Scan operation?
Dynamo DB.Explanation: --projection-expression lets you select only certain attributes in your scan results.

Dynamo DB.Question: Which AWS CLI options should you use to paginate results of a DynamoDB Scan operation and minimize output items?
Dynamo DB.Explanation: --max-items & --starting-token enable pagination and efficient result handling in CLI output.

Dynamo DB.Question: You are developing a banking application that uses DynamoDB to store its data. You want to update both the Exchanges and the AccountBalance tables at the same time or not at all. Which DynamoDB feature allows you to do so?
Dynamo DB.Explanation: DynamoDB Transactions support atomic, all-or-nothing updates across multiple tables/items.

Dynamo DB.Question: DynamoDB Streams records can be sent to the following, EXCEPT ............................
Dynamo DB.Explanation: DynamoDB Streams can be sent to Kinesis Data Streams and Lambda, but not SQS.

Dynamo DB.Question: You have configured a DynamoDB table with a TTL attribute to delete expired user's sessions, but you notice expired items still exist in queries. What should you do?
Dynamo DB.A: Do nothing, DynamoDB automatically delete expired items within 48 hours of the expiration
Dynamo DB.B: This is a known bug in DynamoDB. Use a Lambda function to periodically delete the expired items
Dynamo DB.C: Contact AWS Support to periodically delete expired items
Dynamo DB.Explanation: DynamoDB TTL expires items within 48 hours automatically; temporary presence in queries is normal behavior.

API Gateway.Question: To make a Serverless API, you should integrate API Gateway with .........................
API Gateway.Explanation: API Gateway integrates with AWS Lambda for serverless APIs.

API Gateway.Question: To redirect your API Gateway stage to the correct AWS Lambda Alias, you should use .........................
API Gateway.Explanation: Stage Variables let API Gateway route to different Lambda Aliases.

API Gateway.Question: You can integrate API Gateway with the following, EXCEPT .........................
API Gateway.Explanation: API Gateway does not integrate with AWS CloudShell.

API Gateway.Question: You have created a whole new API (v2) and you want to test it, but you're worried about shifting all the traffic to it. What is the recommended way to test it?
API Gateway.A: Create a whole new Stage, then use Route 53 to distribute traffic between your two Stages using a Weighted record (CNAME)
API Gateway.C: Update all your Lambda functions to use Aliases
API Gateway.Explanation: Canary release lets you test a new version by shifting a portion of traffic

API Gateway.Question: You have an API Gateway backed by a set of Lambda functions and want to mask some fields in the output data. What should you use?
API Gateway.Explanation: Mapping Templates enable output transformation and masking fields in API Gateway.

API Gateway.Question: Which specification allows you to import/export your API as code?
API Gateway.Explanation: Swagger / OpenAPI is the standard for defining APIs as code and for import/export.

API Gateway.Question: Your Lambda-backed API is overloaded and costly. The response is the same all day. What should you do?
API Gateway.Explanation: Enabling caching at the stage reduces invocations and billing for repeatable responses.

API Gateway.Question: API Gateway Caching is defined per ..................... with the default TTL ....................
API Gateway.Explanation: Caching is stage-specific and the default TTL is 300 seconds.

API Gateway.Question: How can clients invalidate the cache of an API from the client-side?
API Gateway.C: Pass the HTTP header Cache-Control: max-age=0
API Gateway.Explanation: Sending "Cache-Control: max-age=0" header from the client invalidates the API cache.

API Gateway.Question: Which API Gateway feature allows you to implement pricing plans for different customers?
API Gateway.Explanation: Usage Plans & API Keys allow you to manage and limit usage for different customers.

API Gateway.Question: You want to troubleshoot a serverless app with API Gateway, Lambda, DynamoDB, and slow/exceptions occur. What should you use?
API Gateway.Explanation: X-Ray visualizes and traces API Gateway, Lambda, and DynamoDB interactions for troubleshooting.

API Gateway.Question: How do you support usage by users from multiple domains for your API?
API Gateway.A: Deploy a new Stage for each user
API Gateway.C: Create a Stage Variable for each user
API Gateway.Explanation: CORS enables cross-domain access for APIs consumed from multiple domains.

API Gateway.Question: You want to authenticate requests made to your API. All requests contain a Bearer token in the Authorization header. These tokens must be validated against a 3rd party provider. What should you use?
API Gateway.C: Cognito User Pools with API Gateway
API Gateway.Explanation: Use Lambda Authorizer to validate tokens from an external/3rd party provider.

API Gateway.Question: You want to authenticate users against Facebook before requests to your API hosted by API Gateway. What should you use for seamless integration?
API Gateway.Explanation: Cognito User Pools integrate with social identity providers for authentication.

API Gateway.Question: Which HTTP error code does API Gateway return when there are too many requests?
API Gateway.Explanation: 429 Too Many Requests is returned for rate limiting or throttling in API Gateway.

API Gateway.Question: Which CloudWatch metric helps analyze timeout issues between API Gateway and a Lambda function?
API Gateway.Explanation: IntegrationLatency shows time API Gateway spends waiting on integrations like Lambda.

API Gateway.Question: API Gateway supports the WebSocket protocol for real-time APIs.
API Gateway.Explanation: API Gateway supports WebSocket protocol for building real-time APIs.

CICD.Question: What is CICD stands for?
CICD.Explanation: Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery is the correct expansion for CICD.

CICD.Question: A company, hosts all their infrastructure in AWS, wants to find an AWS service alternative to GitLab as they want to version control their code entirely in AWS. Which AWS service do you recommend?
CICD.Explanation: AWS CodeCommit is a secure, managed source control service hosting private Git repositories—an alternative to GitLab and GitHub.

CICD.Question: You would like to orchestrate your CICD pipeline to deliver all the way to Elastic Beanstalk. Which AWS service do you recommend?
CICD.Explanation: AWS CodePipeline automates your release pipeline and integrates directly with Elastic Beanstalk for application and infrastructure updates.

CICD.Question: Which AWS service helps you deploy your code to a fleet of EC2 instances with a specific strategy (e.g., Blue/Green deployment)?
CICD.Explanation: AWS CodeDeploy automates deployments to EC2, Fargate, Lambda, and on-premises, supporting blue/green and in-place deployment strategies.

CICD.Question: You have a Jenkins Continuous Integration (CI) build server hosted on-premises and you would like to stop it and replace it with an AWS managed service. Which AWS should you choose?
CICD.Explanation: AWS CodeBuild is a fully managed CI service, compiling code and running tests—an alternative to Jenkins.

CICD.Question: You plan to create a CICD for your application in AWS. You want to run some automated tests before the deployment process. Which AWS service allows you to do so?
CICD.Explanation: AWS CodeBuild can compile code, run tests, and produce artifacts ready for deployment.

CICD.Question: You want to automatically trigger code analysis on every CodeCommit push to detect secret credentials. How can you achieve this?
CICD.A: Setup AWS CloudWatch Events in CodeCommit
CICD.B: Setup AWS SNS / Lambda integration in CodeCommit
CICD.Explanation: SNS/Lambda integration in CodeCommit can trigger workflows like code scanning or alerting on each commit.

CICD.Question: AWS CodeCommit supports the following authentication methods, EXCEPT .........................................
CICD.A: HTTPS with AWS CLI Credential helper
CICD.D: HTTPS with Git Credentials for IAM user
CICD.Explanation: CodeCommit supports HTTPS, SSH, and Git/IAM (not WebSocket) for authentication.

CICD.Question: Your colleague has an IAM user in another AWS Account who wants to access your CodeCommit repository. What should you do?
CICD.A: Share your SSH Keys with him
CICD.B: Generate Git Credentials and share with him
CICD.C: Create an IAM role in your AWS account with the required permissions, then tell him to use STS cross-account access to assume this IAM role
CICD.Explanation: Use cross-account IAM role and STS for secure CodeCommit repository access from another AWS account.

CICD.Question: CodePipeline failed to deploy to Elastic Beanstalk even though the code was pushed to CodeCommit just 10 mins ago. Most likely reason?
CICD.B: CodePipeline is waiting for manual approval
CICD.C: Your CodeBuild stage probably failed some tests
CICD.D: Someone has deleted the Elastic Beanstalk environment
CICD.Explanation: A failed CodeBuild stage halts pipeline deployment, even if commits succeed.

CICD.Question: Manager wants emails when CodePipeline fails. How do you achieve this?
CICD.C: Setup an AWS CloudWatch Event Rule
CICD.Explanation: CloudWatch Event Rules can trigger notifications, including emails, for CodePipeline failures.

CICD.Question: Which AWS service lets you track and audit API calls to/from CodePipeline?
CICD.Explanation: AWS CloudTrail provides audit logs for all CodePipeline API activity.

CICD.Question: The buildspec.yml file must be placed ....................... so CodeBuild can work properly.
CICD.A: in the codebuild/ directory in your code
CICD.B: in the codecommit/ directory in your code
CICD.C: at the root of your code
CICD.Explanation: The buildspec.yml file must be at the root of your code for CodeBuild to recognize it.

CICD.Question: When your CodeBuild build project fails, you can do the following to troubleshoot the issues, EXCEPT .......................
CICD.C: SSH into the CodeBuild container to debug from there
CICD.D: Run CodeBuild locally to reproduce the build
CICD.Explanation: CodeBuild containers cannot be SSH accessed; logs and local reproduction are the available troubleshooting methods.

CICD.Question: You find 15 minutes of each CodeBuild is spent pulling dependencies. How to speed up the build process?
CICD.B: Modify the buildspec.yml to enable Dependencies Caching in Amazon S3
CICD.Explanation: Enabling dependency caching in buildspec.yml with S3 dramatically speeds up builds that pull remote dependencies.

CICD.Question: You want to deploy an SPA to S3 after generating static files from markdown, automatically. Which AWS services should you use?
CICD.Explanation: CodePipeline + CodeBuild lets you build static assets and deploy them to S3 in an automated workflow.

CICD.Question: You manage a fleet of EC2 and on-premises instances where CodeDeploy isn't working on first deployment. What could be a cause?
CICD.A: You've probably forgotten to install and start the CodeDeploy agent on the instances
CICD.B: CodeDeploy doesn't work with on-premises instances
CICD.C: You've forgotten to allow inbound traffic on the CodeDeploy service's security group
CICD.Explanation: CodeDeploy agent must be installed and started on all instances to perform deployments.

CICD.Question: CodeBuild containers are run outside of a VPC and it's impossible to connect to resources in your VPC.
CICD.Explanation: CodeBuild containers can be configured to run inside a VPC for private resource access.

CICD.Question: CodeDeploy supports the following predefined deployment configurations for EC2/on-premises instances, EXCEPT .....................
CICD.Explanation: 'Immutable' is not a supported predefined deployment configuration for CodeDeploy EC2/on-premises (supported: OneAtATime, HalfAtAtime, AllAtOnce).

SAM and CDK.Question: Which of the following commands allows you to upload your Serverless SAM application to AWS?
SAM and CDK.Explanation: The sam deploy command uploads and deploys SAM apps to AWS.

SAM and CDK.Question: You see Transform: 'AWS::Serverless-2016-10-31' in a CloudFormation template. What does this represent?
SAM and CDK.Explanation: 'AWS::Serverless-2016-10-31' indicates a SAM template, used to define serverless resources.

SAM and CDK.Question: AWS SAM supports the following resource types, EXCEPT .................................
SAM and CDK.Explanation: AWS::Serverless::UserPool resource is not supported by AWS SAM.

SAM and CDK.Question: Which SAM Policy Template do you use in a SAM template to give a Lambda function read access to objects in S3 buckets?
SAM and CDK.Explanation: The S3ReadPolicy SAM policy gives Lambda functions read-only access to S3 buckets.

SAM and CDK.Question: ........................ allows you to debug your Lambda functions locally, inspect variables, and execute code line-by-line.
SAM and CDK.Explanation: SAM CLI + AWS Toolkits let you debug Lambda functions locally with advanced features.

SAM and CDK.Question: You want to create your infrastructure in AWS using code, but you don't have time to learn JSON or YAML to write a CloudFormation template. You already know Python. Which AWS service can help you?
SAM and CDK.Explanation: AWS CDK lets you define AWS infrastructure using programming languages like Python, without writing JSON or YAML templates.

Cognito.Question: You want users to log in with Twitter, and allow permission to access their own data in DynamoDB and S3. What do you use?
Cognito.Explanation: Cognito Identity Pools enable federated logins and provide scoped AWS credentials for users to access their own data.

Cognito.Question: Authenticate users against Facebook before they use your API hosted by API Gateway. What do you use for seamless authentication integration?
Cognito.Explanation: Cognito User Pools support direct integration with social identity providers like Facebook for authentication.

Cognito.Question: Log every successful login from Cognito User Pools into RDS for analytics. What do you do?
Cognito.B: Write a Pre-Authentication hook with Lambda
Cognito.C: Write a Post-Authentication hook with Lambda
Cognito.Explanation: Use a Post-Authentication Lambda trigger to log events to an RDS database after successful login.

Cognito.Question: You can customize the following in the Cognito Hosted UI, EXCEPT .....................
Cognito.Explanation: The underlying JavaScript of the Hosted UI cannot be customized, whereas logo, CSS, and URL can be changed.

Cognito.Question: After a successful login using Cognito User Pools, it sends a .............................
Cognito.Explanation: Cognito User Pools return a JWT (JSON Web Token) after successful authentication.

Cognito.Question: Cognito User Pools integrate with the following AWS services to authenticate requests, EXCEPT .....................
Cognito.Explanation: Cognito User Pools cannot integrate with Classic Load Balancers for authentication.

Step Functions and AppSync.Question: You want to orchestrate a series of AWS Lambda functions into a workflow. Which AWS service should you use?
Step Functions and AppSync.Explanation: AWS Step Functions is a low-code visual workflow service used to coordinate AWS services and automate serverless applications.

Step Functions and AppSync.Question: Your developers want a managed GraphQL backend for a mobile application. Which AWS service do you recommend?
Step Functions and AppSync.Explanation: AWS AppSync is a fully managed service to develop GraphQL APIs, handling secure data access and integration with other AWS services.

Step Functions and AppSync.Question: You want to orchestrate multiple Lambda functions and wait for the result of all of them before making a final decision. What do you recommend?
Step Functions and AppSync.A: Step Functions Parallel States and then one final Task State
Step Functions and AppSync.Explanation: Step Functions Parallel States allow multiple Lambda functions to execute concurrently, then continue with a final task state.

Step Functions and AppSync.Question: You have a Step Functions workflow invoking Lambda functions. One state has an error with States.Permissions. How do you solve this problem?
Step Functions and AppSync.A: There's an execution failure in the Lambda function invoked by this Task State
Step Functions and AppSync.B: You need to give the Step Functions workflow the required IAM permissions to execute the Lambda function invoked by this Task State
Step Functions and AppSync.C: The Task State runs longer than the TimeoutSeconds value and it's failed
Step Functions and AppSync.Explanation: States.Permissions error indicates the Step Functions workflow lacks IAM permissions to execute the Lambda function.

Step Functions and AppSync.Question: Which of the following AWS services does not support the WebSocket protocol?
Step Functions and AppSync.Explanation: DynamoDB does not support WebSocket protocol. ALB, API Gateway, and AppSync all support WebSocket connections.

Step Functions and AppSync.Question: You have a GraphQL based API hosted on-premises that you want to migrate to AWS. Which AWS service should you choose?
Step Functions and AppSync.Explanation: AWS AppSync is the managed GraphQL service for migrating and hosting GraphQL APIs on AWS.

Advanced IAM.Question: A company hired you to get some tasks done in their AWS Account. What is the best way to get access to their AWS Account?
Advanced IAM.A: Ask them to create an IAM user for you
Advanced IAM.B: Ask them to send you an AWS Access Key and Secret
Advanced IAM.C: Use the STS service to assume an IAM Role in their AWS Account to gain temporary credentials
Advanced IAM.Explanation: AWS STS lets you assume roles and get temporary cross-account credentials securely.

Advanced IAM.Question: You have an EC2 instance with a removed IAM role, and writes to S3 fail but reads still work. What is the most likely cause?
Advanced IAM.A: The EC2 instance is using cached temporary IAM credentials
Advanced IAM.B: The IAM credentials are cached in the EC2 instance...
Advanced IAM.C: The S3 bucket policy authorizes reads
Advanced IAM.D: When a read is done on a bucket, there's a grace period of 5 minutes...
Advanced IAM.Explanation: S3 bucket policy can independently allow reads, so those operations can still work after the IAM role is removed.

Advanced IAM.Question: What does this IAM policy allow you to do? (Provides EC2 actions + PassRole: arn:aws:iam:::role/RDS-)
Advanced IAM.A: It allows you to assign any IAM role to RDS instances
Advanced IAM.B: It allows you to assign any IAM role to EC2 instances
Advanced IAM.C: It allows you to assign RDS full access to EC2 instances
Advanced IAM.D: It allows you to assign IAM Roles to EC2 if they start with RDS-*
Advanced IAM.Explanation: You can assign IAM Roles to EC2 if the role name starts with 'RDS-'.

Advanced IAM.Question: You want to provide each of 200 IAM users personal space in S3 under /home/<username>. How can you do this efficiently?
Advanced IAM.A: Create an S3 bucket policy and change as users are added...
Advanced IAM.B: Create one customer-managed policy with dynamic variables...
Advanced IAM.C: Create inline policies for each IAM user as they onboarded
Advanced IAM.D: Create one customer-managed policy per IAM user...
Advanced IAM.Explanation: Use a single managed policy with dynamic username variables and attach to a group of all users for simpler management.

Advanced IAM.Question: You are running an on-premises Microsoft Active Directory. You need to create another AD in AWS and establish trust. Which AWS Directory service should you use?
Advanced IAM.Explanation: Managed Microsoft AD enables trust relationships with on-premises Active Directory environments.

Security and Encryption.Question: To enable In-flight Encryption (In-Transit Encryption), we need to have .....................
Security and Encryption.A: an HTTP endpoint with an SSL certificate
Security and Encryption.B: an HTTPS endpoint with an SSL certificate
Security and Encryption.Explanation: In-flight Encryption = HTTPS, and HTTPS cannot be enabled without an SSL certificate.

Security and Encryption.Question: Server-Side Encryption means that the data is sent encrypted to the server.
Security and Encryption.Explanation: Server-Side Encryption means the server will encrypt the data for us. We don’t need to encrypt it beforehand.

Security and Encryption.Question: In Server-Side Encryption, where do the encryption and decryption happen?
Security and Encryption.A: Both Encryption and Decryption happen on the server
Security and Encryption.B: Both Encryption and Decryption happen on the client
Security and Encryption.C: Encryption happens on the server and Decryption happens on the client
Security and Encryption.D: Encryption happens on the client and Decryption happens on the server
Security and Encryption.Explanation: In Server-Side Encryption, the server handles both encryption and decryption, client never sees the key.

Security and Encryption.Question: In Client-Side Encryption, the server must know our encryption scheme before we can upload the data.
Security and Encryption.Explanation: With Client-Side Encryption, the server does not need to know the scheme as it does not perform encryption or decryption operations.

Security and Encryption.Question: You need to create KMS Keys in AWS KMS before you are able to use the encryption features for EBS, S3, RDS ...
Security and Encryption.Explanation: You can use AWS managed service keys in KMS; you don't always need to create your own KMS keys.

Security and Encryption.Question: AWS KMS supports both symmetric and asymmetric KMS keys.
Security and Encryption.Explanation: KMS keys can be either symmetric or asymmetric (RSA/ECC key pairs or 256-bit symmetric).

Security and Encryption.Question: You want to share an encrypted AMI (EBS snapshot using KMS CMK) with another AWS account. What must you do?
Security and Encryption.A: The other AWS account needs to logout and login again
Security and Encryption.B: You need to share the KMS CMK used to encrypt the AMI with the other AWS account
Security and Encryption.C: You can't share an AMI that has an encrypted EBS snapshot
Security and Encryption.Explanation: The KMS CMK used for encryption must also be shared with the other AWS account to allow access to the AMI.

Security and Encryption.Question: What should you use to control access to your KMS CMKs?
Security and Encryption.Explanation: KMS Key Policies are the primary method for controlling access to KMS customer managed keys (CMKs).

Security and Encryption.Question: You want to securely give your Lambda function access to the DB password. What is the most secure option?
Security and Encryption.B: Have it as a plaintext environment variable
Security and Encryption.C: Have it as an encrypted environment variable and decrypt it at runtime
Security and Encryption.Explanation: The most secure solution is to store it encrypted and decrypt it at runtime in the Lambda environment variable.

Security and Encryption.Question: You want to store and track secret value versions over time. Which AWS service should you use?
Security and Encryption.Explanation: SSM Parameter Store can store secrets and has built-in version tracking, storing all previous values of a parameter.

Security and Encryption.Question: Where to store configuration values for your main database to maintain control and version history?
Security and Encryption.Explanation: SSM Parameter Store is the right choice for secure storage with versioning of configuration parameters.

Security and Encryption.Question: Most suitable AWS service for storing RDS DB passwords with automatic rotation?
Security and Encryption.Explanation: AWS Secrets Manager is designed for secret storage, encryption, and supports automatic secret rotation (like for RDS passwords).

Security and Encryption.Question: You would like to encrypt 400 KB of data. You should use .....................
Security and Encryption.B: KMS GenerateDataKey API call and encrypt client-side
Security and Encryption.Explanation: Use Envelope Encryption (KMS GenerateDataKey) for >4 KB of data; KMS Encrypt API has a 4KB limit.

Security and Encryption.Question: S3 bucket with SSE:KMS, EC2 app with S3:GetObject permission gets denied on download. What is a possible cause?
Security and Encryption.Explanation: For SSE:KMS, you must grant KMS:Decrypt to the instance so it can decrypt data from the bucket.

Security and Encryption.Question: How to encrypt an existing CloudWatch Log Group with a KMS key?
Security and Encryption.A: You can enable encryption from the Console
Security and Encryption.Explanation: Use the associate-kms-key API call to add encryption to an existing CloudWatch Log Group.

Security and Encryption.Question: Which IAM policy condition allows you to enforce SSL requests to S3 buckets?
Security and Encryption.Explanation: The aws:SecureTransport condition enforces SSL (HTTPS) for accessing objects in S3 buckets.

Other Services.Question: Which AWS service allows you to send a large number of emails using AWS SDK?
Other Services.Explanation: Simple Email Service (SES) is designed for sending high volumes of email via SDK or SMTP.

Other Services.Question: Which AWS service should you use to centrally manage SSL certificates for ALB and CloudFront?
Other Services.Explanation: AWS Certificate Manager (ACM) manages, provisions, and deploys SSL/TLS certificates at scale for AWS services.

Other Services.Question: Which AWS service helps protect sensitive data in S3 buckets?
Other Services.Explanation: Amazon Macie is a security service that uses ML to automatically discover and protect sensitive data in S3.

Other Services.Question: Which AWS technology do you recommend to implement a search feature with partial matches for DynamoDB data?
Other Services.Explanation: Amazon OpenSearch Service provides full-text search and analytics with support for partial and fuzzy matching, complementing DynamoDB.
